questions.question: What is the fundamental definition of computer memory?

options.text: A physical mechanism that generates the system clock.
A combination of memory cells, where each cell is 8 bits long and stores data as 0s and 1s.
A continuous analog signal storage system used for audio processing.
The central processing unit's arithmetic logic circuitry.

questions.explanation: Computer memory is a combination of memory cells. Each cell length is 8 bits, and every data stored follows bit data such as 0s and 1s.

questions.question: In what form is data stored within computer memory?

options.text: Decimal numbers (0-9).
Hexadecimal codes directly.
Binary form using bits (0s and 1s).
ASCII characters directly.

questions.explanation: Every data item stored in computer memory follows bit data, specifically represented as 0s and 1s.

questions.question: What are the two main types of computer memory?

options.text: Input Memory and Output Memory.
Primary Memory and Secondary Memory.
Volatile Memory and Flash Memory.
Static Memory and Dynamic Memory.

questions.explanation: The breakdown of Computer Memory includes two main branches: Primary Memory and Secondary Memory .

questions.question: What is the Memory Hierarchy?

options.text: The physical sequence of chips on the motherboard.
An organization of memory levels based on speed, cost, and capacity.
The order in which the operating system loads drivers.
A file system structure used for organizing folders.

questions.explanation: Memory hierarchy organizes storage based on fundamental properties where fast storage costs more and has less capacity, while slower storage is cheaper and larger .

questions.question: The memory hierarchy is divided into which two main categories?

options.text: Internal (Primary) and External (Secondary).
Online and Offline storage.
Fast Access and Slow Access.
Digital and Analog memory.

questions.explanation: The hierarchy design is divided into Internal Memory (Primary) and External Memory (Secondary) .

questions.question: Which components are considered part of Internal (Primary) Memory?

options.text: Hard Disk, SSD, and Flash Memory.
CPU Registers, Cache Memory, and Main Memory.
Optical Disk, Magnetic Tape, and Cloud Storage.
Keyboard buffer, Mouse buffer, and Printer spool.

questions.explanation: Internal Memory comprises Main Memory, Cache Memory, and CPU registers. These are directly accessible by the processor.

questions.question: Which components are included in External (Secondary) Memory?

options.text: L1, L2, and L3 Cache.
Registers and Accumulators.
RAM and ROM.
Magnetic Disks, Optical Disks, and Magnetic Tapes.

questions.explanation: External Memory comprises Magnetic Disk, Optical Disk, Magnetic Tape, and other peripheral storage devices.

questions.question: What is the primary role of a Register in the memory hierarchy?

options.text: To store the operating system permanently.
A small storage location in the CPU to temporarily hold data and addresses.
To backup data in case of power failure.
To manage the file system directory structure.

questions.explanation: A register is a small permanent storage location within a CPU used to store or hold data, information, and addresses temporarily.

questions.question: Do CPU registers store data permanently?

options.text: Yes, they retain data even when the computer is off.
No, data stored is temporary and not permanent.
Yes, but only General Purpose Registers.
Yes, they are a type of non-volatile ROM.

questions.explanation: Data in registers is not stored permanently. Registers hold information temporarily for processing.

questions.question: What are the two main types of registers?

options.text: Volatile and Non-Volatile Registers.
Static and Dynamic Registers.
General Purpose Registers and Special Purpose Registers.
Primary and Secondary Registers.

questions.explanation: There are two types of registers: General Purpose Registers and Special Purpose Registers.

questions.question: What describes Cache Memory best?

options.text: One of the slowest memories used for archival.
One of the fastest memories, residing between CPU and Main Memory.
External memory used for large file storage.
Memory located on the network card for internet buffering.

questions.explanation: Cache memory is one of the fastest memories. It resides between the CPU and main memory and stores frequently used data.

questions.question: What happens to the content of Cache Memory when the computer is turned off?

options.text: It is saved to the hard disk automatically.
It remains in the cache for 24 hours.
It is cleared automatically.
It is compressed into the BIOS chip.

questions.explanation: Once the computer gets turned off, the cache memory will be cleared automatically.

questions.question: Which cache levels are typically supported in modern computer systems?

options.text: L1, L2, and L3.
Primary and Secondary only.
A, B, and C levels.
Alpha, Beta, and Gamma.

questions.explanation: Nowadays, modern computer systems support L1, L2, and L3 caches .

questions.question: What is the definition of Main Memory?

options.text: External storage connected via USB.
A small buffer inside the CPU logic unit.
Internal storage availed to store data and programs temporarily or permanently.
A type of magnetic tape used for backups.

questions.explanation: Main memory is an internal storage area in a computer, which is availed to store data and programs either permanently or temporarily.

questions.question: Why is Main Memory considered a critical component?

options.text: It must scale in size, efficiency, and cost to maintain performance growth.
It is the only component that requires cooling.
It provides power to the CPU.
It is the only permanent storage in a computer.

questions.explanation: Main memory is critical for all systems (server, mobile, etc.) and must scale in size, technology, efficiency, and cost to maintain performance benefits.

questions.question: How does the CPU connects to Main Memory?

options.text: Via a direct wireless link.
Through a memory bus (Address and Data buses).
Through the SATA interface.
Using the USB controller.

questions.explanation: Main memory is connected to the CPU via a memory bus, which actually consists of an address bus and a data bus.

questions.question: What is the first step the CPU takes to access data in Main Memory?

options.text: It sends the data directly through the data bus.
It sends a memory address through the address bus.
It waits for the memory to signal availability.
It clears the cache memory.

questions.explanation: The CPU firstly sends a number through an address bus, a number called memory address, that indicates the desired location of data.

questions.question: Main memory is principally divided into which two types?

options.text: Cache and Register.
HDD and SSD.
Virtual and Physical.
RAM and ROM.

questions.explanation: Main memory is divided into RAM (Random Access Memory) and ROM (Read Only Memory) .

questions.question: What defines Secondary Storage?

options.text: Storage that is volatile and extremely fast.
Small storage located directly on the CPU die.
Non-volatile storage outside primary memory, large and inexpensive.
Direct access memory used for active program execution.

questions.explanation: Secondary storage is anything outside of primary memory. It is non-volatile, large, cheap, and does not permit direct instruction execution.

questions.question: Why is secondary storage referred to as 'non-volatile'?

options.text: It does not lose data when the device is powered down.
It loses data instantly when power is lost.
It requires a constant power supply to retain data.
It can never be erased.

questions.explanation: Secondary storage does not lose the data when the device is powered down, making it non-volatile.

questions.question: How does the computer access data from secondary storage?

options.text: Via direct load/store instructions from the CPU.
Through I/O channels, transferring data to an intermediate area in primary storage.
By connecting the storage device directly to the L1 cache.
Using wireless transmission to the ALU.

questions.explanation: The computer uses input/output channels to access secondary storage and transfers the desired data using an intermediate area in primary storage.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a file system in secondary storage?

options.text: To cool down the storage device.
To organize data into files/directories and provide metadata.
To increase the physical speed of the disk rotation.
To convert AC power to DC for the drive.

questions.explanation: The file system provides the abstraction necessary to organize data into files and directories and provides metadata like owner, access time, and permissions.

questions.question: What are the two main types of RAM?

options.text: Flash and Optical.
SRAM and DRAM.
DDR and QDR.
Prom and Eprom.

questions.explanation: The RAM family includes two important memory devices: Static RAM (SRAM) and Dynamic RAM (DRAM).

questions.question: How long does SRAM retain its data?

options.text: For about 4 milliseconds.
As long as electrical power is applied to the chip.
Forever, even without power.
Only while the CPU is reading it.

questions.explanation: SRAM retains its contents as long as electrical power is applied to the chip.

questions.question: What happens to the data in SRAM if power is lost?

options.text: It is automatically saved to the hard drive.
It remains intact for a few hours.
Its contents will be lost forever.
It becomes read-only data.

questions.explanation: If the power is turned off or lost temporarily, the contents of SRAM will be lost forever.

questions.question: What is the typical data lifetime of DRAM without refresh?

options.text: About 4 milliseconds.
About 4 seconds.
About 4 minutes.
Indefinite.

questions.explanation: DRAM has an extremely short data lifetime, typically about four milliseconds, even when power is applied.

questions.question: Why is DRAM useful despite its short data lifetime?

options.text: It doesn't need power.
A controller refreshes the data before it expires.
It is faster than SRAM.
It is non-volatile.

questions.explanation: A DRAM controller is used to refresh the data before it expires, so the contents can be kept alive as long as needed.

questions.question: What technique does DDR SDRAM use to improve performance?

options.text: It increases the voltage to the chip.
It uses 'double pumping' to transfer data on both rising and falling clock edges.
It eliminates the need for a clock signal entirely.
It uses flash memory cells instead of capacitors.

questions.explanation: The DDR interface uses double pumping (transferring data on both the rising and falling edges of the clock signal).

questions.question: What is a key advantage of the DDR SDRAM interface?

options.text: It allows the clock frequency to be lowered, improving signal integrity.
It requires double the power voltage.
It makes the memory non-volatile.
It removes the need for a memory controller.

questions.explanation: Keeping the clock frequency down reduces the signal integrity requirements on the circuit board.

questions.question: How does DDR2 differ from standard DDR SDRAM regarding data transfers?

options.text: It performs four transfers per clock instead of two.
It performs one transfer per clock.
It transfers data only on the rising edge.
It uses a slower internal bus.

questions.explanation: While DDR transfers data two times per clock, DDR2 SDRAM can perform four transfers per clock.

questions.question: What technique allows DDR2 to double the bandwidth without increasing cell frequency?

options.text: Overclocking.
Multiplexing with a wider internal bus.
Liquid cooling.
Using SRAM cells.

questions.explanation: DDR2 uses a bus that is twice as wide and I/O buffers that perform multiplexing to increase bandwidth without increasing operational frequency.

questions.question: What is the defining characteristic of Read Only Memory (ROM)?

options.text: It is volatile and fast.
It is non-volatile and data stored cannot be easily modified.
It requires constant refreshing.
It is used primarily for user file storage.

questions.explanation: ROM is non-volatile; it holds programs/data permanently when switched off, and stored data cannot be modified (in standard ROM).

questions.question: What critical program is typically stored in ROM?

options.text: The Microsoft Office suite.
The Bootstrap Loader.
The User's Desktop configuration.
The Internet Browser cache.

questions.explanation: ROM stores a program called the bootstrap loader that helps start up the computer.

questions.question: Which of the following is a type of ROM?

options.text: DDR3
SRAM
SDRAM
EEPROM

questions.explanation: Types of ROM include PROM, EPROM, EEPROM, and Flash ROM.

questions.question: What describes PROM (Programmable Read Only Memory)?

options.text: It can be erased by sunlight.
It is empty when manufactured and can be permanently programmed by the user once.
It is reprogrammable multiple times via software.
It loses data when power is off.

questions.explanation: PROM is empty of data when manufactured and may be permanently programmed by the user.

questions.question: How is an EPROM (Erasable Programmable ROM) erased?

options.text: By applying a high voltage electrical signal.
By shining ultra-violet light through a small window on the chip.
By formatting it in the operating system.
By removing the battery.

questions.explanation: The EPROM chip has a small window allowing it to be erased by shining ultra-violet light on it.

questions.question: What distinguishes EEPROM from EPROM?

options.text: It uses magnets to store data.
It is reprogrammed electrically without using UV light.
It is volatile.
It cannot be reprogrammed.

questions.explanation: EEPROM is reprogrammed electrically without using Ultraviolet light.

questions.question: What is Flash ROM?

options.text: A type of memory that requires a camera flash to program.
Similar to EEPROM but can be reprogrammed while still in the computer.
A volatile memory used for graphics.
A storage device made of moving parts.

questions.explanation: Flash ROM is similar to EEPROM but can be reprogrammed while still in the computer, making upgrades easier.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a core characteristic used to differentiate storage technologies?

options.text: Volatility.
Accessibility.
Color.
Mutability.

questions.explanation: Core characteristics include Volatility, Differentiation, Accessibility, Addressability, and Mutability.

questions.question: Which set represents the four types of computer storage devices mentioned?

options.text: RAM, ROM, Cache, Register.
Magnetic, Optical, Flash, and Online Cloud Storage.
Keyboard, Monitor, Printer, Mouse.
USB, Firewire, Thunderbolt, Ethernet.

questions.explanation: The four types listed are Magnetic Storage, Optical Storage, Flash Memory, and Online Cloud Storage devices.

questions.question: What is the smallest unit of computer memory?

options.text: Byte.
Nibble.
Bit.
Word.

questions.explanation: The bit is defined as the smallest unit of computer memory.

questions.question: How many bits constitute one Byte?

options.text: 4 bits.
8 bits.
16 bits.
32 bits.

questions.explanation: 1 Byte = 8 bits.

questions.question: How many bytes are in 1 Kilobyte (KB)?

options.text: 1000 bytes.
1024 bytes.
512 bytes.
2048 bytes.

questions.explanation: 1 Kilobyte = 1024 bytes.

questions.question: What is the definition of 'Endianness'?

options.text: The speed of data transfer on the bus.
The physical size of the memory chip.
The order in which bytes are arranged within a digital word.
The error-checking capability of RAM.

questions.explanation: Endianness refers to the order in which bytes are arranged within a larger data type (digital word) in memory.

questions.question: What defines Big Endian format?

options.text: The Least Significant Byte is at the smallest address.
The Most Significant Byte is at the smallest memory address.
Bytes are arranged randomly.
Nibbles are swapped within each byte.

questions.explanation: In Big Endian, the Most Significant Byte (MSB) is stored at the smallest memory address.

questions.question: What defines Little Endian format?

options.text: The Most Significant Byte is at the smallest address.
The Least Significant Byte (LSB) is stored at the smallest memory address.
The middle bytes are stored first.
The data is stored in reverse bit order.

questions.explanation: In Little Endian, the Least Significant Byte (LSB) is stored at the smallest memory address.

questions.question: If the value 0x12345678 is stored in Big Endian at address 0x00, what is the byte sequence?
questions.explanation: In Big Endian, the MSB (12) is first. The sequence is 12, 34, 56, 78 .

questions.question: If the value 0x12345678 is stored in Little Endian at address 0x00, what is the byte sequence?
questions.explanation: In Little Endian, the LSB (78) is first. The sequence is 78, 56, 34, 12 .

questions.question: What fundamental principle governs the design of the memory hierarchy?

options.text: Faster storage technologies cost more per byte and have less capacity.
All memory types cost the same but differ in size.
Larger memory is always faster than smaller memory.
Slower memory is more volatile than faster memory.

questions.explanation: Fast storage technologies cost more per byte and have less capacity, while slower technologies are cheaper and larger .

questions.question: Why is a memory hierarchy approach important?

options.text: It complicates the hardware design to increase cost.
It balances speed, cost, and capacity to improve overall system performance.
It ensures that all data is stored in volatile memory.
It allows the CPU to access the Hard Disk directly.

questions.explanation: The memory hierarchy approach organizes memory to bridge the gap between CPU speed and memory speed, optimizing for performance and cost.
